title: ABC Segmentation
text: business financial analytics, ABC classification method widely used categorize items, customers, groups according contribution total metric. abc() function provides flexible robust way perform ABC segmentation, either based transaction counts sum numeric variable sales margin revenue.

title: ABC Segmentation
text: abc(): Segments dataset categories (, B, C, etc.) based cumulative contribution. Allows custom break points (e.g., top 10% = , next 40% = B, etc.). Works grouped tibbles database-backed objects. Returns segment object, processed calculate() produce table results.

title: ABC Segmentation
text: fpaR::abc() requires grouped tibble lazy DBI object using dplyr::group_by() specific groups drive contribution Value Capture .value provided, function sums per group; otherwise, counts rows. Segment Object Creation function creates segment object stores necessary metadata later computation. Category Values Table 1 explains break points cumulative want see stores make top 40% revenue follow top 70% 90% put c(0.4,.7,.9,1) Table 1

title: ABC Segmentation
text: function returns segment object. Use calculate() generate ABC classification table: wanted return results, use fpaR::calculate() Table 2
code: # Example  contoso::sales |>     dplyr::group_by(store_key) |>     fpaR::abc(       category_values = c(0.4,.7,.9,1),        .value = margin       )  ── ABC Classification ────────────────────────────────────────────────────────── Function: `ABC` was executed  ── Description: ──  This calculates a rolling cumulative distribution of variable and segments each group member's contribution by the break points provided. Helpful to know which group member's proportational contribution to the total.  ── Category Information ──  • The data set is grouped by the margin and segments each group member by their first NA entry to define their cohort margin • This creates cohort ID that each member is assigned to eg; January 2020, February 2020, etc • The distinct count of each margin member in the cohort is then tracked over time ── Calendar: ── • The calendar aggregated NA to the day time unit • A NA calendar is created with 1 groups • Calendar ranges from 0 to 0 • 0 days were missing and replaced with 0 • New date column NA was created from NA ── Actions: ── ✔Aggregate ✖Shift ✖Compare ✔Proportion Of Total ✖Count Distinct  ── Next Steps: ──  • Use `calculate()` to return the results ──────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────── contoso::sales |>     dplyr::group_by(store_key) |>     fpaR::abc(       category_values = c(0.4,.7,.9,1),        .value = margin       ) |>     fpaR::calculate()

title: Standard vs. 5-5-4 Calendar
text: Calendars essential tools organizing, tracking, reporting business activities. financial planning, reporting, retail analytics, two common calendar systems widely used: Standard Calendar 5-5-4 Calendar vignette explains differences calendars typical use cases.

title: Standard vs. 5-5-4 Calendar
text: standard calendar follows conventional Gregorian calendar: 12 months varying lengths (28–31 days) 52 weeks per year (sometimes 53 leap years) Months uneven length, can cause challenges period--period comparisons. Example: Use Cases: General business reporting Financial statements based actual months Year--year month--month analysis

title: Standard vs. 5-5-4 Calendar
text: 5-5-4 calendar retail accounting calendar designed simplify period--period comparisons: quarter 13 weeks, divided three periods: 5 weeks, 5 weeks, 4 weeks month quarter fixed number weeks (rather days) years include 53rd week align solar calendar Example Quarter 5-5-4 Calendar: Use Cases: Retail businesses consistent weekly reporting crucial Comparing performance across periods without affected uneven month lengths Planning promotions, inventory, sales cycles aligned weeks rather calendar months

title: Standard vs. 5-5-4 Calendar
text: Understanding difference standard 5-5-4 calendars helps organizations choose right system reporting needs. standard calendars common financial statements general business operations, 5-5-4 calendar preferred retail consistent period comparisons operational planning.

title: Cohort
text: Cohort analysis common method tracking groups users, customers, entities time understand retention, behavior, trends. cohort() function fpaR provides database-friendly implementation cohort analysis compatible duckdb snowflake backends. combines functionality multiple traditional cohort tables single streamlined workflow.

title: Cohort
text: cohort(): Assigns member dataset time-based cohort based first occurrence .date column. Aggregates distinct counts cohort members time. Supports multiple calendar types ("standard" "554"). Can summarize cohorts various time_units (day, week, month, quarter, year). Returns segment object, can processed using calculate() generate cohort table.

title: Cohort
text: Assign Cohorts member .value assigned cohort date, first date appear .date. Aggregate Time function counts distinct members per cohort across time periods defined time_unit. Database Efficiency function optimized DBI objects, generating SQL-compatible operations using dbplyr. Internal Execution internal function cohort_fn(): Floors dates chosen time_unit. Groups members cohort date. Computes distinct counts period IDs. Reshapes table wide format analysis.

title: Cohort
text: function returns segment object. Use calculate() retrieve cohort table:
code: library(dplyr)  # Example cohort analysis seg_obj <- cohort(.data = contoso::sales,                   .date = order_date,                   .value = customer_key,                   calendar_type = "standard",                   time_unit = "month",                   period_label = FALSE)  # Calculate the cohort table cohort_tbl <- calculate(seg_obj) cohort_tbl <- dplyr::collect(cohort_tbl)  # if using a DBI objec

what: what is going on under the hood
title: Getting started
text: financial planning analysis, common compare year--date (YTD) metrics previous year’s YTD understand performance trends. function yoytd_fn() provides functionality. internal, non-exported function, called [yoytd()] executed [calculate()]. vignette explains function , works, work output.

title: Getting started
text: yoytd_fn() performs following: Computes current year--date (YTD) values. Computes previous year--date (PYTD) values, optionally applying lag. Joins YTD PYTD tables together date, year, grouping variables. Fills missing dates downward consistency. Summarizes data summing YTD PYTD values group. output DBI object can converted tibble using dplyr::collect() analysis.

title: Add Comprehensive Date-Based Attributes to a DBI lazy frame or tibble object — augment_calendar
text: function takes data frame date column generates wide set derived date attributes. include start/end dates year, quarter, month, week; day--week indicators; completed remaining days time unit; additional convenience variables weekend indicators. designed time-based feature engineering useful reporting, forecasting, time-series modeling, data enrichment workflows.

title: Add Comprehensive Date-Based Attributes to a DBI lazy frame or tibble object — augment_calendar
Add Comprehensive Date-Based Attributes to a DBI lazy frame or tibble object — augment_calendar
text: .data data frame tibble containing least one date column. .date column containing Date values, passed using tidy-eval (e.g., {{ date_col }}).

title: Add Comprehensive Date-Based Attributes to a DBI lazy frame or tibble object — augment_calendar
text: dbi  tibble containing original data along generated date-based attributes.

title: Add Comprehensive Date-Based Attributes to a DBI lazy frame or tibble object — augment_calendar
text: function creates following groups attributes: 1. Start end dates year_start_date, year_end_date quarter_start_date, quarter_end_date month_start_date, month_end_date week_start_date, week_end_date 2. Day--week fields day_of_week – numeric day week (1–7) day_of_week_label – ordered factor label (e.g., Mon, Tue, …) 3. Duration fields days_in_year – total days year interval days_in_quarter – total days quarter interval days_in_month – total days month 4. Completed/remaining days days_complete_in_week, days_remaining_in_week days_complete_in_month, days_remaining_in_month days_complete_in_quarter, days_remaining_in_quarter days_complete_in_year, days_remaining_in_year 5. Miscellaneous weekend_indicator – equals 1 Saturday Sunday; otherwise 0 date-derived fields ending _date coerced class Date.

title: Current period year-to-date — ytd
code: library(contoso) ytd(sales,.date=order_date,.value=quantity,calendar_type="standard") #>  #> ── Year-to-date ──────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────── #> Function: `ytd` was executed #>  #> ── Description: ── #>  #> This creates a daily `cumsum()` of the current year quantity from the start of #> the standard calendar year to the end of the year #>  #> ── Calendar: ── #>  #> • The calendar aggregated order_date to the day time unit #> • A standard calendar is created with 0 groups #> • Calendar ranges from 2021-05-18 to 2024-04-20 #> • 222 days were missing and replaced with 0 #> • New date column date and year was created from order_date #>  #> ── Actions: ── #>  #> ✔Aggregate quantity #> ✖Shift #> ✖Compare #> ✖Proportion Of Total #> ✖Count Distinct #>  #>  #> ── Next Steps: ── #>  #> • Use `calculate()` to return the results #> ──────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────── #>

title: Current period year-to-date compared to full previous period — ytdopy
code: library(contoso) ytdopy(sales,.date=order_date,.value=quantity,calendar_type='standard',lag_n=1) #>  #> ── Year-to-date over full previous year ──────────────────────────────────────── #> Function: `ytdopy` was executed #>  #> ── Description: ── #>  #> This creates a daily `cumsum()` of the current year quantity and compares it #> with the full year `sum()` previous year quantity from the start of the #> standard calendar year to the end of the year #>  #> ── Calendar: ── #>  #> • The calendar aggregated order_date to the day time unit #> • A standard calendar is created with 0 groups #> • Calendar ranges from 2021-05-18 to 2024-04-20 #> • 222 days were missing and replaced with 0 #> • New date column date and year was created from order_date #>  #> ── Actions: ── #>  #> ✔Aggregate quantity #> ✔Shift 1 year #> ✔Compare previous year #> ✖Proportion Of Total #> ✖Count Distinct #>  #>  #> ── Next Steps: ── #>  #> • Use `calculate()` to return the results #> ──────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────── #>
